3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

Chapter 5        Within a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the       Bennets were particularly intimate. Sir William Lucas had been       formerly in trade in Meryton, where he had made a tolerable       fortune, and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to       the king during his mayoralty. The distinction had perhaps been       felt too strongly. It had given him a disgust to his business       and to his residence in a small market town; and, quitting       them both, he had removed with his family to a house about a mile       from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge, where he       could think with pleasure of his own importance, and, unshackled       by business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all the       world. For, though elated by his rank, it did not render him       supercilious; on the contrary, he was all attention to everybody.       By nature inoffensive, friendly, and obliging, his presentation       at St. James’s had made him courteous.        Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a       valuable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. The       eldest of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about       twenty-seven, was Elizabeth’s

That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk       over a ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the       assembly brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to       communicate.        “_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte,” said Mrs. Bennet with       civil self-command to Miss Lucas. “_You_ were Mr. Bingley’s first       choice.”        “Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”        “Oh! you mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice.       To be sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her—indeed I rather       believe he _did_—I heard something about it—but I hardly know       what—something about Mr. Robinson.”        “Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson;       did not I mention it to you? Mr. Robinson’s asking him how he       liked our Meryton assemblies, and whether he did not think there       were a great many pretty women in the room, and _which_ he       thought the prettiest? and his answering immediately to the last       question—‘Oh! the eldest Miss Bennet, beyond a doubt, there       cannot be two opinions on that point.’”        “Upon my word! prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:
Outline: 1. Mr. Bennet is informed by a letter from Mr. Collins that he is soon to inherit the Longbourn estate, as Mr. Bennet has no sons. He relays this news to his wife and five daughters.

2. The Bennet family meets Mr. Collins, their new neighbor, at a ball. Mr. Collins is a very pompous and self-important man, and Elizabeth Bennet takes an instant dislike to him.

3. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth, who politely declines. He then asks her sister, Jane, who also declines.

4. Mr. Bingley, a wealthy young man, rents the nearby estate of Netherfield Park. He, his sister, and his good friend Mr. Darcy come to town and attend a ball at the assembly rooms.

5. At the ball, Mr. Darcy dances only once, with Miss Bingley. He appears haughty and aloof, and Elizabeth Bennet overhears Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy talking about her, in which Mr. Darcy calls her “tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me.”

6. Jane Bennet becomes ill and has to stay at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes to stay with her, and during her stay, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy begin to get to know each other better and form a tentative friendship.

7. Elizabeth returns home, and Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to visit. The two men are very different in their behavior towards the Bennet sisters – Mr. Bingley is warm and friendly, while Mr. Darcy is reserved and aloof.

8. Mr. Bingley invites the Bennet sisters to a ball at Netherfield Park. Elizabeth goes, against her mother’s wishes, and has a very enjoyable time. Mr. Darcy dances with her twice, and they appear to be getting along well.

9. Mr. Collins proposes to Elizabeth again, and she once again refuses him. He then asks her younger sister, Lydia, who accepts.

10. Lydia Bennet elopes with Mr. George Wickham, a young man of dubious character. Mr. Wickham had formerly been friends with Mr. Darcy, but the two had a falling out.

11. Mr. Bennet goes to London to try and find Lydia and Mr. Wickham. Elizabeth goes with him, and while they are there they run into Mr. Darcy, who is also in search of the eloping couple.

12. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy find Lydia and Mr. Wickham and persuade them to return to Longbourn. Lydia is married to Mr. Wickham in a hasty ceremony.

13. Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy leave for London, and it is evident that Mr. Bingley is very much in love with Jane. Elizabeth is worried that Mr. Darcy may have been responsible for separating the two.

14. Elizabeth visits her friend, Charlotte Lucas, who is now married to Mr. Collins. Elizabeth is not happy with the marriage, as she feels that Charlotte has sacrificed herself for security.

15. Elizabeth receives a letter from Jane, who is now in London. Jane has met Mr. Bingley’s sister, Miss Bingley, and she is not impressed.

16. Elizabeth goes to stay with her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner in Derbyshire. While there, she visits Pemberley, the estate of Mr. Darcy. She is surprised to find that she feels welcome there, despite her initial dislike of Mr. Darcy.

17. Elizabeth and the Gardiners run into Mr. Darcy while they are touring Pemberley. He is cordial and polite, and Elizabeth begins to see him in a new light.

18. Elizabeth returns home, and shortly thereafter Mr. Darcy comes to visit. He proposes to her, and after initially refusing him, she finally accepts.

19. The Bennet sisters are all married and settled, and the novel ends with a reflection on the importance of marriage for happiness and security.

prompt:

2. Mrs. Hudson, their landlady, comes in to announce that a gentleman is there to see Holmes 
3. The gentleman turns out to be an old friend of Holmes', Mr. Stamford, who has come to offer him a place to stay at his boarding house

5. Stamford leaves and Holmes soon returns, excited to have a new case 
6. He explains that a woman, Mrs. Warren, came to see him and told him about her husband's strange behavior 
7. Mrs. Warren's husband, Neville, has been acting very strangely since he came back from India and she is worried about him 
8. Holmes and Watson go to Mrs. Warren's house to meet Neville 
9. Neville is a tall, thin man with a very dark complexion and he is very nervous 
10. He tells them that he has been having nightmares and that he is afraid to go to sleep 
11. Mrs. Warren tells them that Neville has been behaving very differently since he came back from India and she is worried about him 
12. Holmes and Watson go to India to try to find out what happened to Neville 
13. They meet with Neville's old friend, Colonel Sebastian Moran, who tells them that Neville was involved in a very strange incident while he was in India 
14. Moran tells them that Neville was part of a group of British soldiers who were attacked by a group of native Indians 
15. The Indians were led by a man called the Maharaja, who was a very powerful magician 
16. The Maharaja put a spell on Neville and the other soldiers, which made them all very ill 
17. Neville was the only one who survived and he was sent back to England 
18. Moran tells Holmes and Watson that he believes the Maharaja is still after Neville and that he is in danger

20. The Maharaja tells them that he is not after Neville and that he is not a magician 
21. He tells them that Neville is in danger from someone else 
22. Holmes and Watson go back to England and they find out that Neville has been murdered 
23. They also find out that Moran was the one who killed him 
24. Moran is arrested and Holmes and Watson solve the case

A lady steps out of her carriage and is immediately surrounded by a group of men who start fighting with each other. One of the men is Holmes, who is trying to protect the lady. He gets hit and falls to the ground. Irene Adler helps an injured man, even though she is being watched by Sherlock Holmes, who is trying to blackmail her. Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson set off a smoke bomb in order to distract a crowd and allow them to escape. A man is pretending to be injured and is carried into a woman's home. He knows she will try to save her most precious belongings in a fire, so he starts a fire and she grabs the photograph he is looking for. Someone has stolen a photograph from a house, and Sherlock Holmes is on the case. He and a companion will call on the house tomorrow morning to try to find the thief and retrieve the photograph. Irene Adler is married, and Sherlock Holmes is in hopes that she loves her husband, because it would spare the King of Bohemia all fear of future annoyance. The woman in the passage has left England, and the person she was speaking to (Sherlock Holmes) is surprised and disappointed. He had been hoping to get some information from her. Irene Adler is an actress who has masqueraded as a man before. She followed Sherlock Holmes to his home and then ran off to her husband. They are leaving because the king wronged them and they have a photograph to prove it. In the passage, Holmes is discussing with the King how a woman's wit has bested his plans. He seems to be impressed by the woman, and the King offers to reward him. Holmes requests the woman's photograph, and the King agrees. In the autumn of last year, Sherlock Holmes was in deep conversation with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. I was about to withdraw when Holmes pulled me abruptly into the room and closed the door behind me. The stout gentleman was Mr. Wilson, Holmes' partner and helper in many of his most successful cases. A man comes to Sherlock Holmes to tell him about a very strange series of events. It is not clear if a crime has been committed, but the story is very curious. The passage describes a man who is seeking Sherlock Holmes' help. The man is average-looking, except for his red hair and disgruntled expression. Holmes deduces from the man's appearance that he has done manual labor at some point. The speaker uses Mr. Jabez Wilson's physical appearance to deduce that he is a manual laborer, a Freemason, and has recently been to China. The passage describes a man's reaction to an advertisement seeking red-headed men for a job that pays 4 pounds a week. The man is incredulous and wonders what the job could entail. Holmes finds the whole situation amusing and encourages the man to tell his story. This passage describes a man's assistant, who is very good at his job but likes to take pictures in his spare time. The man says that he is willing to work for less than he is worth because he enjoys learning the business. The passage describes a man who is considering joining the League of the Red-headed Men. He is told that the vacancy is worth quite a fortune, and that there are more vacancies than there are men. He is also told that the trustees are at their wits end what to do with the money. A man tells his friend about a vacancy at the League, a organization that provides easy berths to red-headed men living in London. The pay is good and there is very little work required. This passage describes a man's experience answering an advertisement for a red-headed man. He is amazed at the number of redheads who show up for the job, and his companion Spaulding encourages him to continue despite the competition.

Last chunk: Now, if you cared to apply, Mr. Wilson, you would just walk in; but perhaps it would hardly be worth your while to put yourself out of the way for the sake of a few hundred pounds.’  “Now, it is a fact, gentlemen, as you may see for yourselves, that my hair is of a very full and rich tint, so that it seemed to me that if there was to be any competition in the matter I stood as good a chance as any man that I had ever met. Vincent Spaulding seemed to know so much about it that I thought he might prove useful, so I just ordered him to put up the shutters for the day and to come right away with me. He was very willing to have a holiday, so we shut the business up and started off for the address that was given us in the advertisement.  “I never hope to see such a sight as that again, Mr. Holmes. From north, south, east, and west every man who had a shade of red in his hair had tramped into the city to answer the advertisement. Fleet Street was choked with red-headed folk, and Pope’s Court looked like a coster’s orange barrow. I should not have thought there were so many in the whole country as were brought together by that single advertisement. Every shade of colour they were—straw, lemon, orange, brick, Irish-setter, liver, clay; but, as Spaulding said, there were not many who had the real vivid flame-coloured tint. When I saw how many were waiting, I would have given it up in despair; but Spaulding would not hear of it. How he did it I could not imagine, but he pushed and

There was a double stream upon the stair, some going up in hope, and some coming back dejected; but we wedged in as well as we could and soon found ourselves in the office.”  “Your experience has been a most entertaining one,” remarked Holmes as his client paused and refreshed his memory with a huge pinch of snuff. “Pray continue your very interesting statement.”  “There was nothing in the office but a couple of wooden chairs and a deal table, behind which sat a small man with a head that was even redder than mine. He said a few words to each candidate as he came up, and then he always managed to find some fault in them which would disqualify them. Getting a vacancy did not seem to be such a very easy matter, after all. However, when our turn came the little man was much more favourable to me than to any of the others, and he closed the door as we entered, so that he might have a private word with us.  “‘This is Mr. Jabez Wilson,’ said my assistant, ‘and he is willing to fill a vacancy in the League.’  “‘And he is admirably suited for it,’ the other answered. ‘He has every requirement. I cannot recall when I have seen anything so fine.’ He took a step backward, cocked his head on one side, and gazed at my hair until I felt quite bashful.
